subject: Re: May a thousand alphabets blossom!
msgSnippet: Hi all, ... The problem with the books is that we already have an alphabet for them. Not a very good one, but all the thousands of books use it. That s its
messageBody:
Hi all,

John Zuck wrote:
>Hi, Paige, I know I've settled back to just lurking, but these last 3
>posts--one of a sample (Yay!) brought me out of my shell.
>I think we all can agree -- no matter if we might like to fantasize
>about books written in QS, that it's primary attraction is that it's
>phonetic, logical, and just a cool alternative script.

The problem with the books is that we already have an alphabet for
them. Not a very good one, but all the thousands of books use it.
That's its only strength, the reason why it is irreplacable. QS had
certain advantages above traditional writing in other situations
though, that are quite attractive to everyone. Like its speed and ease
in writing and still being readable and its ease in lerning. Maybe we
shouldn't want QS to take over the world (sounds even a bit
sectarian). But when we can point people to the great advantages of
the alphabet like any other shorthand system, they might want to learn
it too.

John Zuck wrote:
>As for myself, I actually used QS to write my journal for a couple of
>months, but felt myself wanting something more personal still, and
>developed a personal shorthand incorporating elements of TO, QS, Gregg
>shorthand, Forkner shorthand, and my own inventions. It's still
>changing a little, but is fairly stable as far as most glyphs go. I
>just find writing in it strangely satisfying. I can't explain it.

Can you share some of your shorthand with us? I'm very interested...

John Zuck wrote:
>Paige go for it, please present your QS/Shaw fusion!
>Jerry, way to go with your Snelsgrift
>Chuck, thanks for presenting your QS hand!
>People, please post your poems, papers, papyri and paragraphs!
>May ten thousand samples be posted! May a thousand alphabets blossom!

Amen!

Jerry
